data.text: Want to know more about events where we meet young people? Head to our website https://t.co/0ZrRnWcFKe
Thanks to all participants for sharing their experiences, and to @BancodePortugal for hosting the event! Muito obrigado! Watch the event in full here https://t.co/qOvdikxRC7
What did the participants take away from the event? Susana Reis, working in the supervision department of a Portuguese bank, shares her views https://t.co/yrVvSnZPSI
One of the key challenges banks face is how to increase diversity in top banking jobs. Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria explained why diversity is key https://t.co/3ktTcQ58VY

Another topic discussed was the role of banks in the fight against climate change. André Braga, who works in strategic planning, explains what banks can do to tackle climate change https://t.co/QB3e44I6hc

Bernardo Caldas, one of the young professionals at the event, works as a data scientist. Watch him talking about how artificial intelligence changes the way banks operate and what challenges this brings https://t.co/f6f6u6KIfl

#fintech and its impact on banks was one of the topics discussed. While customers will eventually benefit from the competition fintech brings to the sector, supervisors need to look out for BigTech, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. Watch more https://t.co/9QZgXuQZdu

What challenges are banks currently facing? Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria and @bancodeportugal’s Vice-Governor Elisa Ferreira talked to young Portuguese bankers about climate change, AI, and more in the latest #ECBYouthDialogue. Read more https://t.co/k0v07aqpVz https://t.co/vmFOg8p0gc

Quais os desafios que os bancos enfrentam atualmente? Andrea Enria, Presidente do Conselho de Supervisão, e Elisa Ferreira, Vice-Governadora do @bancodeportugal, falaram com jovens profissionais sobre vários temas no #ECBYouthDialogue. Mais informação https://t.co/k947atMVso https://t.co/2pt6EqlUD4

In a letter to banks, the ECB asks CEOs to report on how their institutions plan to ensure a smooth transition to alternative or reformed interest rate benchmarks – certain changes to relevant benchmark rates will be introduced as early as October 2019 https://t.co/qxjDvtYQCr
Euro area bank interest rate statistics (May 2019) https://t.co/dm2NrmPsyi

Speech Luis de Guindos: Macroprudential policy ten years after the crisis https://t.co/KK6PwbTK1e
Letter Andrea Enria, Chair of the Supervisory Board, to Mr Zanni and Mr Valli, MEPs, on stress tests https://t.co/jWqrRjjbij (EN) https://t.co/HbudUuhW6r (IT)
What would you like to ask our new Chief Economist Philip R. Lane? Post your question using #AskECB and follow his answers live on Tuesday, 9 July. https://t.co/zwlj42AVxN
Speech Philip R. Lane: Welcome address at the ECB conference on “Challenges in the digital age” https://t.co/ctCTX99WwV
Households and non-financial corporations in the euro area (Q1 2019) https://t.co/v9PCgMWAB4
Euro area quarterly balance of payments and international investment position (Q1 2019) https://t.co/c5ZoxkWfGW
Interview Philip R. Lane with Yle https://t.co/qH9UthqiBg
Occasional paper: Macroprudential stress test of the euro area banking system https://t.co/aCxAeMKqGM
Euro money market statistics (3rd maintenance period 2019) https://t.co/HTMtvivxBT

Philip R. Lane: The ECB has been active and creative in the design of its policy stance by deploying non-standard measures to combat drift away from the target. Further easing can be provided if required to deliver our mandate. Read the speech here https://t.co/tRHCfZgGOy 5/5

Philip R. Lane: The successful anchoring of inflation expectations depends on how much the central bank shows that it is a learning organisation committed in its search for the most effective policy tools in delivering its mandate 4/5
Philip R. Lane: Consistent and clear communication is key in maintaining focus on the inflation objective, especially during an extended phase of below-target inflation outcomes 3/5

Philip R. Lane: Our current policy mix – which includes the negative policy rate, forward guidance, reinvestment after the end of asset purchases and TLTROs – shows that we can provide the monetary policy accommodation required to return inflation to our medium-term goal 2/5

[THREAD] In his speech at the Bank of Finland, ECB Chief Economist Philip R. Lane spoke about the effectiveness of the policy instruments that the ECB has been deploying to ensure that inflation heads towards our objective over the medium-term 1/5 https://t.co/lxqUcRY2oH
Speech Philip Lane: Monetary Policy and Below-Target Inflation https://t.co/a3EbZ5myE8
Monetary developments in the euro area (May 2019) https://t.co/p9JY4TtdBP

We have invited Urban Sketchers from the Frankfurt area to our building today, to sketch its interior and our view of Frankfurt city.

The new €100 and €200 banknotes have been in circulation for one month! Have you already spotted what’s new? They are smaller and have upgraded security features such as the satellite hologram! Learn more about the #NewBanknotes https://t.co/p9TrThoB8p https://t.co/rPxDqNcjx4

We are proud to celebrate our European identity by hosting art from all across the EU. This year we are very excited to feature contemporary art from Croatia.
 
Curious about the art on display at the ECB? Download our free ECB Art App to find out more https://t.co/y1H45H9qrR https://t.co/Uvt2ziYcZp

As part of the transition from EONIA to €STR, the new short-term rate coming later this year, the working group on euro risk-free rates recently asked for feedback on a legal action plan. A summary of the feedback received is now available https://t.co/ToF3Z5YTvJ https://t.co/tDCXg4hNjh

Thanks for following today’s discussions. Live coverage of the #ECBForum resumes tomorrow from 10:30 CET.  
Take a look at the photos from today https://t.co/ZJ0scLpfTH #EUROat20 https://t.co/UnNpmJkyZV
LIVE: the policy panel at the #ECBForum on Central Banking #EUROat20 https://t.co/CO2KIKZvhE
Coming up shortly – the #ECBForum policy panel. Watch live here on Twitter from 16:00 CET #EUROat20 https://t.co/Wzrd3VyH3V
Be that as it may, that trust it is now the bedrock upon which our leaders can and will build the next steps of our EMU. Read the full speech here https://t.co/RCZogfDErB 11/11

For some, that trust may lie in a genuine faith in our common destiny. For others it comes from the appreciation of the greater prosperity so far achieved. For yet others that trust may be forced by the increased and unavoidable closeness of our countries. 10/11
Overall, the journey of the past twenty years has strengthened the conviction of our peoples that it is only through more Europe that the implications of this integration can be managed. 9/11
The journey towards greater integration that started twenty years ago is far from finished. Success has been broad but uneven. 8/11
In the current environment, what matters is that monetary policy remains committed to its objective and does not resign itself to too-low inflation. 7/11
In the absence of improvement, such that the sustained return of inflation to our aim is threatened, additional stimulus will be required. 6/11

Just as our policy framework has evolved in the past to counter new challenges, so it can again. In the coming weeks, the Governing Council will deliberate how our instruments can be adapted commensurate to the severity of the risk to price stability. 5/11

Our capacity to react in this way was made possible by the flexibility embedded in our mandate. The recent ruling of the European Court of Justice emphasised the broad discretion of the ECB in using all our tools in a necessary and proportionate way to achieve our objective. 4/11

We responded in three main ways: by clarifying the symmetry of our aim, by laying out the tools we would use to counteract downside inflation risks and by operationalising our reaction function by launching a series of new instruments. 3/11

The first decade of Monetary Union was characterised by calm macroeconomic conditions, with limited volatility and steady economic growth. The second decade, however, has seen profound shifts in the prevailing environment. Our monetary policy strategy has had to adapt. 2/11
[THREAD] In his speech at the #ECBForum, President Mario Draghi spoke about the past twenty years of the ECB’s monetary policy and the outlook for the future. #Euroat20 1/11 https://t.co/XhxSfiplRG

Economic Bulletin: 29 to 53 soft patches (depending on the definition) since 1970 but only five recessions
Economic Bulletin: Soft patches are quite common and are not a reliable indicator of cyclical turning points
Economic Bulletin box: Definitions and characteristics of soft patches in the euro area https://t.co/8eaz4WeqHG
Economic Bulletin: Phillips curves can account for euro area underlying inflation except for the latest outturns
Economic Bulletin: Phillips curves are simple yet useful models linking inflation to activity and other drivers
